title: Jeremiah Chapter 39 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 39 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 39 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 39.

questions.question: In which year of King Zedekiah's reign did Nebuchadrezzar besiege Jerusalem?
options: Ninth year
Tenth year
Eleventh year
Twelfth year
questions.correctAnswer: Ninth year
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:1 states that Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon came against Jerusalem in the ninth year of Zedekiah.

questions.question: What happened to the city of Jerusalem in the eleventh year of Zedekiah, in the fourth month?
options: The city was broken up
The city was rebuilt
The city was flooded
The city was blessed
questions.correctAnswer: The city was broken up
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:2 mentions that the city was broken up in the eleventh year of Zedekiah, in the fourth month, on the ninth day.

questions.question: Who were sitting in the middle gate when the princes of Babylon came in?
options: Nergalsharezer, Samgarnebo, Sarsechim, and others
Zedekiah and his nobles
Jeremiah and his disciples
The priests of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Nergalsharezer, Samgarnebo, Sarsechim, and others
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:3 lists the princes of the king of Babylon sitting in the middle gate, including Nergalsharezer and others.

questions.question: How did King Zedekiah escape from Jerusalem?
options: By night through the king's garden
By the main city gate at noon
By the river Jordan
Through a secret tunnel
questions.correctAnswer: By night through the king's garden
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:4 describes Zedekiah fleeing at night by the way of the king's garden, through the gate between two walls.

questions.question: Where was Zedekiah taken after being captured by the Chaldeans?
options: Riblah in the land of Hamath
Babylon
Jericho
Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Riblah in the land of Hamath
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:5 states that Zedekiah was brought to Nebuchadnezzar at Riblah in the land of Hamath for judgment.

questions.question: What was done to the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes?
options: They were slain by the king of Babylon
They were sent into exile
They were made priests
They were set free
questions.correctAnswer: They were slain by the king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:6 explains that the king of Babylon slew the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes.

questions.question: What punishment was given to Zedekiah by the king of Babylon?
options: His eyes were put out and he was bound with chains
He was crowned king of Babylon
He was exiled to Egypt
He was set free
questions.correctAnswer: His eyes were put out and he was bound with chains
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:7 states that Zedekiah's eyes were put out and he was bound with chains to be carried to Babylon.

questions.question: What did the Chaldeans do to the king's house and the houses of the people in Jerusalem?
options: They burned them with fire and broke down the walls
They restored them
They sold them to foreigners
They left them intact
questions.correctAnswer: They burned them with fire and broke down the walls
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:8 describes how the Chaldeans burned the king's house and the houses of the people, and broke down the walls of Jerusalem.

questions.question: Who carried away the remnant of the people into Babylon?
options: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard
Nebuchadrezzar himself
Jeremiah
Zedekiah
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:9 tells that Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard carried away the remnant of the people into Babylon.

questions.question: True or False: Nebuzaradan left the poor of the land in Judah and gave them vineyards and fields.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:10 confirms that Nebuzaradan left the poor in the land of Judah and gave them vineyards and fields.

questions.question: Who was Jeremiah delivered to after being taken out of prison?
options: Gedaliah the son of Ahikam
Zedekiah
Nebuchadrezzar
Ebedmelech the Ethiopian
questions.correctAnswer: Gedaliah the son of Ahikam
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:14 states Jeremiah was committed to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam to live among the people.

questions.question: True or False: The word of the LORD came to Jeremiah while he was free and preaching among the people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:15 explains that the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah while he was shut up in the court of the prison.

questions.question: To whom did the LORD instruct Jeremiah to go and speak?
options: Ebedmelech the Ethiopian
Zedekiah the king
Nebuzaradan the captain
Gedaliah the son of Ahikam
questions.correctAnswer: Ebedmelech the Ethiopian
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:16 instructs Jeremiah to speak to Ebedmelech the Ethiopian as the LORD directs.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 39:17: 'But I will deliver thee in that day, saith the LORD: and thou shalt not be given into the hand of the men of whom thou art ____.'
options: afraid
jealous
proud
ignorant
questions.correctAnswer: afraid
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:17 states that the LORD will deliver Ebedmelech and he shall not be given into the hand of the men he is afraid of.

questions.question: True or False: Because Ebedmelech put his trust in God, the LORD promised he would fall by the sword.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:18 promises that because Ebedmelech trusted in the LORD, he would not fall by the sword but be delivered.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 39 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 39 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Jeremiah 39, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during adversity?
options: Trust in God’s deliverance even when circumstances seem bleak
Rely only on human strength to overcome difficulties
Avoid trusting God to prevent disappointment
Ignore God’s promises and focus on worldly solutions
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God’s deliverance even when circumstances seem bleak
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:17-18 shows God promising to deliver Ebedmelech from danger because of his trust in the Lord. This encourages believers to trust God’s care even in trials. Supporting verses: Jeremiah 39:15-18, 39:10.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 39 teach us about the importance of obedience to God's commands during difficult times?
options: Obedience leads to God’s protection and favor
Obedience has no impact on outcomes
Obedience is optional in hardship
God punishes obedience with hardship
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience leads to God’s protection and favor
questions.explanation: Jeremiah was obeyed and cared for by Nebuzaradan because God instructed so (Jeremiah 39:11-14). Ebedmelech’s trust and obedience led to God’s deliverance (Jeremiah 39:16-18).

questions.question: Based on Jeremiah 39, what should a Christian's response be when facing the consequences of sin or disobedience?
options: Accept God’s judgment but continue to trust in His mercy
Deny responsibility and blame others
Rebel against God’s discipline
Ignore the consequences and continue sinning
questions.correctAnswer: Accept God’s judgment but continue to trust in His mercy
questions.explanation: The chapter shows Jerusalem’s destruction as judgment (Jeremiah 39:8-9), but God’s mercy remains evident in delivering Jeremiah and Ebedmelech (Jeremiah 39:11-18).

questions.question: What lesson about humility and contentment can be drawn from the treatment of the poor left in Judah according to Jeremiah 39?
options: Contentment can be found even in humble circumstances with God’s provision
The poor should be envied and pitied
We should seek wealth to avoid hardship
God ignores the needs of the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Contentment can be found even in humble circumstances with God’s provision
questions.explanation: Nebuzaradan left the poor in the land and gave them vineyards and fields (Jeremiah 39:10), showing God’s provision for humble trust and contentment.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear of persecution. Based on Jeremiah 39, what encouragement would you share?
options: God promises to deliver those who trust Him from fear and harm
Fear is a sign of weak faith and should be ignored
Persecution means God has abandoned you
Avoid trusting God to prevent disappointment
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to deliver those who trust Him from fear and harm
questions.explanation: God assured Ebedmelech he would not be delivered into the hand of those he feared (Jeremiah 39:16-17), encouraging trust in God’s protection.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 39 illustrate the Christian virtue of integrity under pressure?
options: Jeremiah remained faithful to God despite imprisonment and danger
Jeremiah compromised his faith to save himself
Jeremiah abandoned his message when threatened
Jeremiah acted deceitfully to avoid capture
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah remained faithful to God despite imprisonment and danger
questions.explanation: Jeremiah was imprisoned but remained obedient to God’s word and was protected (Jeremiah 39:14-15), showing integrity during trials.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 39 teach about God's faithfulness in fulfilling His word?
options: God’s words come to pass exactly as He declares
God’s words are often broken
God’s promises are conditional on human merit alone
God changes His mind frequently
questions.correctAnswer: God’s words come to pass exactly as He declares
questions.explanation: Verse 16 states God’s words for evil upon the city will be accomplished, demonstrating God’s faithfulness and sovereignty.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 39, God instructed Nebuzaradan to harm Jeremiah during the Babylonian captivity.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: God commanded Nebuzaradan to take care of Jeremiah and do him no harm (Jeremiah 39:12).

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 39 shows that God’s judgment does not spare the leaders who lead people into sin.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The sons of Zedekiah and the nobles of Judah were killed as part of judgment (Jeremiah 39:6), showing accountability of leaders.

questions.question: When Zedekiah fled the city, what does Jeremiah 39 teach us about the consequences of trying to escape God's judgment?
options: Fleeing from God's judgment leads to capture and harsher consequences
It is wise to avoid judgment by fleeing
God always spares those who run away
Judgment can be escaped by hiding
questions.correctAnswer: Fleeing from God's judgment leads to capture and harsher consequences
questions.explanation: Zedekiah fled but was captured and blinded, showing that trying to avoid God's judgment leads to suffering (Jeremiah 39:4-7).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 39 teach about the importance of prayer and intercession in times of crisis?
options: God responds to faithful intercession by protecting and delivering His people
Prayer is ineffective during judgment
Intercession should be avoided in hardship
Only rulers should pray during crises
questions.correctAnswer: God responds to faithful intercession by protecting and delivering His people
questions.explanation: Jeremiah’s faithful ministry, even in prison, led to God’s protection (Jeremiah 39:11-14), illustrating the power of prayer and intercession.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: God promised Ebedmelech that his life would not fall by the ______, but would be for a prey unto him.
options: sword
fire
flood
famine
questions.correctAnswer: sword
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:18 says Ebedmelech’s life shall not fall by the sword but will be for a prey unto him because of his trust in God.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 39 teach about God's provision for those who lack material wealth?
options: God provides for the poor by leaving some in the land with vineyards and fields
God ignores the poor entirely
The poor must fend for themselves without help
Only the rich receive God’s blessings
questions.correctAnswer: God provides for the poor by leaving some in the land with vineyards and fields
questions.explanation: Nebuzaradan left the poor in the land and gave them vineyards and fields to sustain them (Jeremiah 39:10), showing God’s provision.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 39 encourage believers to live with gratitude and contentment?
options: By trusting God’s provision even in limited circumstances
By always seeking more material wealth
By comparing themselves to others
By resenting their situation
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God’s provision even in limited circumstances
questions.explanation: God’s provision for the poor left in Judah (Jeremiah 39:10) teaches believers to be content and grateful for what God supplies.

questions.question: What can we learn from Jeremiah 39 about perseverance through trials?
options: Perseverance in faith leads to God’s protection and eventual restoration
Trials are a sign of God’s rejection
It is best to give up when trials come
Avoiding trials is always possible
questions.correctAnswer: Perseverance in faith leads to God’s protection and eventual restoration
questions.explanation: Jeremiah remained faithful in prison and was protected and eventually released, illustrating perseverance in faith (Jeremiah 39:14-15).

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 39 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 39.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 39:1, who led the siege against Jerusalem, and what does this event symbolize in the broader biblical narrative?
options: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon, symbolizing God's judgment on Judah
Pharaoh king of Egypt, symbolizing foreign oppression
Cyrus king of Persia, symbolizing restoration
Darius king of Persia, symbolizing God's sovereignty
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon, symbolizing God's judgment on Judah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:1 identifies Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon as the leader of the siege, which is a fulfillment of Jeremiah's prophecies about God's judgment on Judah for their disobedience.

questions.question: What is the significance of the timing mentioned in Jeremiah 39:2, 'the eleventh year of Zedekiah, in the fourth month, the ninth day', in relation to the fall of Jerusalem?
options: It marks the exact date when the city was breached, fulfilling prophetic timelines
It indicates a period of peace before the fall
It represents the beginning of Zedekiah's reign
It coincides with the Passover festival
questions.correctAnswer: It marks the exact date when the city was breached, fulfilling prophetic timelines
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:2 specifies this date as when Jerusalem was broken up, aligning with prophetic warnings and historical records, emphasizing the fulfillment of divine judgment.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 39:3, several Babylonian princes are named. What does the presence of these officials at the 'middle gate' symbolize in the context of ancient Near Eastern siege warfare and political control?
options: The establishment of Babylonian authority and complete control over Jerusalem
A diplomatic meeting to negotiate peace
A religious ceremony to honor Marduk
A defensive strategy by Jerusalem's leaders
questions.correctAnswer: The establishment of Babylonian authority and complete control over Jerusalem
questions.explanation: The princes sitting at the middle gate (Jeremiah 39:3) symbolize the Babylonian takeover and administrative control following the city's fall, a common practice in ancient Near Eastern conquests.

questions.question: Jeremiah 39:4 describes Zedekiah's escape from the city at night. What is the literary and thematic significance of his flight 'by the way of the king's garden, by the gate betwixt the two walls'?
options: It highlights the king's desperation and the collapse of royal power
It symbolizes a secret alliance with the Babylonian army
It represents a ritual purification before exile
It foreshadows his triumphant return to power
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights the king's desperation and the collapse of royal power
questions.explanation: The description of Zedekiah's secretive and desperate escape (Jeremiah 39:4) underscores the complete downfall of Judah's monarchy and fulfillment of Jeremiah's prophecies.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 39:5, where was Zedekiah taken after being captured, and why is this location historically significant?
options: Riblah in the land of Hamath, a known site for judgment and execution by Babylon
Babylon, the capital city where he was imprisoned
Jericho, where he was initially captured
Egypt, where he sought refuge
questions.correctAnswer: Riblah in the land of Hamath, a known site for judgment and execution by Babylon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:5 states Zedekiah was brought to Riblah, a strategic military site used by Babylon for trials, emphasizing the procedural aspect of his judgment.

questions.question: What does the execution of Zedekiah’s sons before his eyes (Jeremiah 39:6) symbolize in the biblical narrative and ancient Near Eastern culture?
options: The total destruction of his lineage and a public display of power
An act of mercy to prevent future rebellion
A religious sacrifice to the Babylonian gods
A diplomatic gesture to Judah's nobles
questions.correctAnswer: The total destruction of his lineage and a public display of power
questions.explanation: Executing the sons before Zedekiah (Jeremiah 39:6) was a brutal method to ensure no successor and to break the spirit of Judah, fulfilling the prophecy of judgment.

questions.question: What is the significance of the blinding of Zedekiah as described in Jeremiah 39:7, especially in the context of biblical symbolism and Near Eastern royal practices?
options: It represents the loss of kingly power and divine favor
It was a ritual purification before exile
It symbolizes enlightenment through suffering
It was a common punishment for rebellious priests
questions.correctAnswer: It represents the loss of kingly power and divine favor
questions.explanation: Blinding Zedekiah (Jeremiah 39:7) symbolized the total removal of his authority and a mark of disgrace, consistent with ancient practices to neutralize defeated kings.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 39:8 describes the burning of the king’s house and the walls of Jerusalem as a metaphorical prophecy rather than an actual event.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:8 clearly states that the Chaldeans burned the king’s house and broke down the walls, indicating a literal historical event, not just metaphorical prophecy.

questions.question: What role did Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, play in the aftermath of Jerusalem’s fall according to Jeremiah 39:9-10?
options: He executed the deportation and spared the poor, giving them land in Judah
He negotiated Jerusalem’s surrender
He served as the new governor of Judah
He was responsible for rebuilding the city
questions.correctAnswer: He executed the deportation and spared the poor, giving them land in Judah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:9-10 describes Nebuzaradan’s role in carrying away captives but leaving the poor in the land with vineyards and fields, showing a nuanced Babylonian policy.

questions.question: Why did Nebuchadrezzar command Nebuzaradan to treat Jeremiah well (Jeremiah 39:11-12), and what does this reveal about Jeremiah’s role and reputation?
options: Because Jeremiah was a prophet who had foretold the fall, deserving protection
Because Jeremiah bribed the Babylonian officials
Because Jeremiah was a relative of Nebuchadrezzar
Because Jeremiah escaped the city unnoticed
questions.correctAnswer: Because Jeremiah was a prophet who had foretold the fall, deserving protection
questions.explanation: Nebuchadrezzar’s instructions (Jeremiah 39:11-12) reflect respect for Jeremiah’s prophetic office and the recognition of his accurate warnings about Jerusalem’s destruction.

questions.question: What does the transfer of Jeremiah to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam (Jeremiah 39:14), signify about the Babylonian approach to governance and the preservation of some Judean leadership?
options: It shows Babylon’s strategy to govern Judah through local proxies
It indicates Jeremiah was being imprisoned further
It reflects a rejection of all Judean leaders
It was a religious sanction by the priests
questions.correctAnswer: It shows Babylon’s strategy to govern Judah through local proxies
questions.explanation: Jeremiah’s placement with Gedaliah (Jeremiah 39:14) demonstrates Babylon’s policy to maintain control by appointing local leaders loyal to them as governors.

questions.question: How does the prophecy given to Ebedmelech in Jeremiah 39:16-18 reflect the theme of divine justice and mercy in the face of Jerusalem's destruction?
options: It promises deliverance for the faithful despite coming judgment
It foretells complete annihilation without hope
It suggests Ebedmelech will become king
It warns that all Ethiopians will be punished
questions.correctAnswer: It promises deliverance for the faithful despite coming judgment
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 39:16-18, God promises to bring disaster on Jerusalem but to save Ebedmelech because of his trust, illustrating divine justice paired with mercy.

questions.question: The term 'Chaldeans' used in Jeremiah 39:5 and 39:8 refers to which group, and what is the significance of this designation in the context of biblical history?
options: Babylonians, highlighting their role as agents of God’s judgment
Egyptians, indicating foreign invaders
Assyrians, the previous oppressors of Judah
Persians, the future liberators
questions.correctAnswer: Babylonians, highlighting their role as agents of God’s judgment
questions.explanation: The 'Chaldeans' in these verses refer to Babylonians, who are presented as instruments of divine judgment against Judah, consistent with other biblical usage.

questions.question: In the historical and cultural context of Jeremiah 39, what does the destruction of the city walls (Jeremiah 39:8) symbolize in terms of Judah’s political and spiritual state?
options: The total collapse of Judah’s defense and protection, both physically and spiritually
A temporary setback with imminent rebuilding
A ritual cleansing of the city
An act to fortify the city further
questions.correctAnswer: The total collapse of Judah’s defense and protection, both physically and spiritually
questions.explanation: Breaking down the walls (Jeremiah 39:8) symbolized the destruction of Judah's security and God's judgment, indicating both political defeat and spiritual failure.

questions.question: How does the narrative of Jeremiah’s imprisonment and release in Jeremiah 39 demonstrate the theme of prophetic vindication and divine protection?
options: Jeremiah is protected and restored, showing God’s faithfulness to His servants
Jeremiah is abandoned and forgotten, showing human rejection
Jeremiah escapes secretly without Babylonian knowledge
Jeremiah becomes king after Zedekiah
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah is protected and restored, showing God’s faithfulness to His servants
questions.explanation: Jeremiah’s release from prison and protection by Babylonian officials (Jeremiah 39:11-14) illustrate divine protection and fulfillment of God's promises to His prophet.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 39 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 39 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 39, which king of Babylon besieged Jerusalem during the reign of Zedekiah?
options: Nebuchadrezzar
Cyrus
Nebuzaradan
Darius
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:1 explicitly states that Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon besieged Jerusalem. This demonstrates God's sovereign use of pagan kings to execute judgment (Isaiah 45:1; Daniel 4:17; Jeremiah 25:9; Revelation 17:17).

questions.question: What event marked the fall of Jerusalem as recorded in Jeremiah 39?
options: The city was broken up
The king repented
The temple was rebuilt
The walls were strengthened
questions.correctAnswer: The city was broken up
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:2 describes the city being broken up, indicating the destruction of Jerusalem. This fulfills prophetic warnings about judgment because of sin (Psalm 79:1; Lamentations 2:3; Ezekiel 7:12; 2 Kings 25:10).

questions.question: Who were the officials that came and sat in the middle gate of Jerusalem according to Jeremiah 39?
options: Princes of the king of Babylon
Priests of Israel
Egyptian envoys
Persian governors
questions.correctAnswer: Princes of the king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:3 names the princes of the king of Babylon sitting in the middle gate, showing the authority Babylon exercised over Judah, reflecting God's judgment through foreign powers (Daniel 2:37-38; Ezra 1:2; Isaiah 10:5; Jeremiah 27:6).

questions.question: How did King Zedekiah escape the city during the Babylonian siege?
options: Fled by night through the king’s garden
Surrendered publicly at the gate
Was taken prisoner in the temple
Escaped by hiding in the walls
questions.correctAnswer: Fled by night through the king’s garden
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:4 recounts Zedekiah fleeing by night through the king’s garden, illustrating human attempts to evade divine judgment which ultimately fail (Psalm 139:7-10; Jonah 1:3; Proverbs 19:21; Romans 1:18-20).

questions.question: Where was Zedekiah taken after being captured by the Chaldean army?
options: Riblah in the land of Hamath
Babylon
Jericho
Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Riblah in the land of Hamath
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:5 shows Zedekiah was brought to Riblah for judgment by Nebuchadnezzar, illustrating God's sovereign orchestration of events and justice (Genesis 50:20; Romans 8:28; Psalm 75:7; Acts 17:26).

questions.question: What cruel act did Nebuchadnezzar commit before Zedekiah’s eyes?
options: Slew Zedekiah’s sons
Burned the temple
Blinded the priests
Destroyed the city gates
questions.correctAnswer: Slew Zedekiah’s sons
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:6 states that Nebuchadnezzar slew Zedekiah’s sons before his eyes, demonstrating the severity of divine judgment and the consequences of rebellion (Deuteronomy 28:50; Lamentations 3:66; Ezekiel 9:6; Hebrews 12:6).

questions.question: What was done to King Zedekiah after his sons were killed?
options: His eyes were put out and he was bound with chains
He was crowned king of Babylon
He was released to rule in Jerusalem
He was sent into exile in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: His eyes were put out and he was bound with chains
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:7 records the blinding and binding of Zedekiah, signifying the complete removal of his power and fulfilling the judgment for his disobedience (Judges 16:21; 2 Kings 25:7; Luke 22:63-65; Revelation 3:17).

questions.question: What did the Chaldeans do to the city of Jerusalem after capturing it?
options: Burned the houses and broke down the walls
Built a temple for their god
Restored the city walls
Made it their new capital
questions.correctAnswer: Burned the houses and broke down the walls
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:8 describes the burning of houses and destruction of walls, showing the totality of God's judgment on unrepentant sin (2 Kings 25:9; Psalm 74:3-8; Ezekiel 5:12; Lamentations 2:7).

questions.question: Who was left in the land of Judah after the Babylonian captivity and what were they given?
options: The poor; vineyards and fields
The priests; the temple
The nobles; houses in Babylon
The soldiers; weapons and armor
questions.correctAnswer: The poor; vineyards and fields
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:10 explains that the poor who had nothing were left and given vineyards and fields, illustrating God’s mercy and providence even amid judgment (Psalm 9:9; Isaiah 61:1-3; Matthew 5:3; James 2:5).

questions.question: What specific instructions did Nebuchadrezzar give regarding Jeremiah?
options: Do him no harm and obey him
Execute him immediately
Send him to Babylon as a prisoner
Ignore his prophecies
questions.correctAnswer: Do him no harm and obey him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:12 records Nebuchadrezzar’s instruction to protect Jeremiah and obey him, highlighting God's protection of His messengers even in captivity (Psalm 91:4; Acts 9:15-16; Isaiah 54:17; 2 Timothy 4:17).

questions.question: To whom was Jeremiah committed after his release from prison?
options: Gedaliah son of Ahikam
Nebuzaradan the captain
Zedekiah’s son
Ebedmelech the Ethiopian
questions.correctAnswer: Gedaliah son of Ahikam
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:14 states Jeremiah was given to Gedaliah, who governed Judah under Babylon, demonstrating God’s providential care for His servants (Jeremiah 40:5; 2 Kings 25:22; Isaiah 10:6; Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What was the content of God’s word to Jeremiah while he was imprisoned?
options: God would bring evil upon Jerusalem
God would restore Jerusalem immediately
God would make Zedekiah king again
God would destroy Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: God would bring evil upon Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:16 reveals God’s declaration of judgment on Jerusalem for their sinfulness, consistent with the prophets' themes of divine justice (Isaiah 13:6; Ezekiel 7:3; Lamentations 1:8; Romans 1:18).

questions.question: Who was the recipient of the prophetic message from God through Jeremiah, promising deliverance?
options: Ebedmelech the Ethiopian
Zedekiah
Gedaliah
Nebuzaradan
questions.correctAnswer: Ebedmelech the Ethiopian
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:16-18 records a special promise of deliverance given to Ebedmelech for his trust in God, illustrating God’s faithfulness to those who put their hope in Him (Psalm 34:18; Isaiah 41:10; Hebrews 13:5; 1 Peter 2:9).

questions.question: What assurance did God give to Ebedmelech about his life during the coming judgment?
options: He will not be given into the hand of his enemies
He will become king of Judah
He will be taken to Babylon
He will be blinded
questions.correctAnswer: He will not be given into the hand of his enemies
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:17 assures Ebedmelech that he will be delivered from the men he fears, demonstrating God’s protective care for the faithful (Psalm 91:7; Isaiah 43:2; Matthew 10:29-31; Romans 8:31).

questions.question: Why did God promise to deliver Ebedmelech according to Jeremiah 39?
options: Because he put his trust in the LORD
Because he was a Babylonian official
Because he fled the city early
Because he was a soldier
questions.correctAnswer: Because he put his trust in the LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 39:18 highlights that deliverance comes as a result of trust in God, emphasizing the biblical doctrine of faith and reliance on God for salvation (Psalm 37:5; Proverbs 3:5-6; Hebrews 11:6; Ephesians 2:8-9).
